issue.title: Array arguments

labels.name: type:proposal
labels.description: A proposal for a new feature

issue.body:
It would be useful to have a way to pass an array as an argument, without requiring the developer to deal with its serialization/deserialization.

In particular, I would like that repeated args are available as a bash array:

```
foo:
  DO +BAR \
    --color=red
    --color=blue
    --color=green

BAR:
  COMMAND
  ARG color
  RUN \
    for c in "${color[@]}"; \
      do echo $c; \
    done
``` 

Right now, arg repetition makes the target being called multiple times in parallel, but I found this other behavior more intuitive. 

Wondering what other people thinks about this

issue.title: private targets

labels.name: type:proposal
labels.description: A proposal for a new feature

issue.body:
## Use case
Having private targets and UDCs (that can only be called from others within the same Earthfile) would help us create more maintainable and decoupled inter-dependencies, while keeping the implementation modularized.

This is important at this stage, when we want to start growing the [earthly/lib](https://github.com/earthly/lib) offering.  

## Expected Behavior
- Having a way to express that a target/UDC is private
- Failing when it is called externally
- `earthly doc` only showing public targets/UDCs

## Possible implementations

### `private` keyword
```
VERSION 0.7

PUBLIC_UDC:
    COMMAND
    RETURN +_IMPLEMENTATION_DETAIL --arg=foo

private IMPLEMENTATION_DETAIL:
    COMMAND
    ARG arg
    RUN echo $arg
```

### Underscore meaning private
```
VERSION 0.7

PUBLIC_UDC:
    COMMAND
    RETURN +_IMPLEMENTATION_DETAIL --arg=foo

_IMPLEMENTATION_DETAIL:
    COMMAND
    ARG arg
    RUN echo $arg
```

### Others

Ideas?

issue.title: buildkit scheduler error: return leaving incoming open
issue.body:
We've been seeing the following error mostly in CI, however, we've also seen it on a developer's machine as well. The issue reproduced on the developer machine several times and only went away after changing the base image of the target (seems sort of random, but perhaps the team can make more sense of it). 

```
Error: build target: build main: failed to solve: unlazy force execution: buildkit scheduler error: return leaving incoming open. Please report this with BUILDKIT_SCHEDULER_DEBUG=1
```

On CI, the job often fails multiple times in a row if you just re-run it as is. I haven't really been able to make sense of why it comes and goes yet.

EDIT by the Earthly team: To get unstuck in this situation you can restart buildkit with `docker stop earthly-buildkitd`.

EDIT 2 by the Earthly team: Possibly related issue: https://github.com/earthly/earthly/issues/2454 (inconsistent graph state error).

EDIT 3 by the Earthly team: This is now a top priority for us. We will provide weekly updates on this issue until it is resolved.

comment.body: Just a quick update: Earthly Satellites now also contain this update. If auto-updates are enabled (they are by default), you should be getting this overnight.

issue.title: Runc error when running Earthly under a Rosetta VM on Mac M1
issue.body:
**What went wrong?**
I attempted to run Earthly on a x86 Ubuntu VM running on my M1 macbook. Sample Earthfile:

```
VERSION 0.7
FROM debian:stable-slim

test:
  RUN apt-get update
```

When running this target:

```
 Init 🚀
————————————————————————————————————————————————————————————————————————————————

           buildkitd | Found buildkit daemon as docker container (earthly-buildkitd)

 Build 🔧
————————————————————————————————————————————————————————————————————————————————

  debian:stable-slim | --> Load metadata debian:stable-slim linux/amd64
               +base | --> FROM debian:stable-slim
               +base | [----------] 100% resolve docker.io/library/debian:stable-slim@sha256:6fe30b9cb71d604a872557be086c74f95451fecd939d72afe3cffca3d9e60607
               +test | --> RUN apt-get update
               +test | runc run failed: unable to start container process: waiting for init preliminary setup: read init-p: connection reset by peer
               +test | ERROR Earthfile line 5:2
               +test |       The command
               +test |           RUN apt-get update
               +test |       did not complete successfully. Exit code 1

============================= ❌ FAILURE [Build 🔧] ==============================

Repeating the output of the command that caused the failure
               +test *failed* | --> RUN apt-get update
               +test *failed* | runc run failed: unable to start container process: waiting for init preliminary setup: read init-p: connection reset by peer
               +test *failed* | ERROR Earthfile line 5:2
               +test *failed* |       The command
               +test *failed* |           RUN apt-get update
               +test *failed* |       did not complete successfully. Exit code 1
```

<!-- Can you reproduce it? If so, please list the steps to reproduce the issue. -->

<!-- Do you have an Earthfile that you can share which showcases the problem? If so, please include it here. -->

**What should have happened?**
I expected the target to run to completion (especially given it's simplicity). 

**Other Helpful Information**

You can reproduce this on an M1 mac:

1. Install [OrbStack](https://orbstack.dev/)
2. Create a new x86 Ubuntu VM (set CPU type to Intel)
3. Install Docker + Earthly
4. Run the `test` target from the previously given Earthfile

It's quite possible this is a bug in OrbStack, Docker, and/or Rosetta. However, creating an example Dockerfile with the below contents:

```
FROM debian:stable-slim

RUN apt-get update
```

And then building it on the same machine has no issue. So, Earthly is doing something unique here that I cannot figure out. Perhaps if I understood it more I might be able to figure out exactly where the issue is.

commits.message:
Registry proxy: support container for Mac (#3420)

Enables image registry proxy support for Mac via a side-car `socat`
container. On Mac, `docker pull` (and friends) will make requests to
`localhost`. These requests will be answered by the `socat` container
and proxied through to the registry proxy server spawned by the CLI.
That server then sends the request to BK (remote or local) via the gRPC
tunnel.

Depends on: https://github.com/earthly/buildkit/pull/30

https://github.com/earthly/earthly/issues/3412

pull_request.title: Registry proxy: support container for Mac
pull_request.body:
Enables image registry proxy support for Mac via a side-car `socat` container. On Mac, `docker pull` (and friends) will make requests to `localhost`. These requests will be answered by the `socat` container and proxied through to the registry proxy server spawned by the CLI. That server then sends the request to BK (remote or local) via the gRPC tunnel. 

Depends on: https://github.com/earthly/buildkit/pull/30

https://github.com/earthly/earthly/issues/3412

issue.title: Cannot log in with ed25519 ssh keys
issue.body:
**What went wrong?**
I try to run `earthly account login` in the sample devcontainer and get this error:
`Error: failed to login: failed executing ping request: failed refreshing expired auth token: agent: failed to sign challenge`

This error is deterministic. Looking at the logs of my ssh agent (1Password), I saw this line with a matching timestamp to running `earthly`:
`Error handling sign request: Key(expected Ed25519 signing but found an RSA algorithm)`

**What should have happened?**
The login process should have been able to sign the challenge with my ssh key (which is on my earthly account).

No known workaround other than just not using ed25519 keys. The [instructions on GitHub for creating ssh keys](https://docs.github.com/en/authentication/connecting-to-github-with-ssh/generating-a-new-ssh-key-and-adding-it-to-the-ssh-agent) defaults to ed25519 keys and refers to systems using RSA keys as "legacy", so switching to RSA does not seem like a good solution.

**Other Helpful Information**
Earthly's ssh login code asks the agent to sign the key but assumes that the key is an RSA key, so [it uses an RSA-specific flag in the signing request](https://github.com/earthly/earthly/blob/main/cloud/auth.go#L542C86-L542C86). Reading [this IETF spec on ssh agents](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-miller-ssh-agent-10.html#name-private-key-operations) it looks like 1Password is correctly refusing to sign the challenge data because the RSA flags are not valid for the key type (ed25519).

I think the change to Earthly shouldn't be too involved - it likely just needs to pass 0 for the flags when signing with non-RSA keys. I think #2246 meant to address this use case.
